newsitem.title: URUGUAY: World Bank urges Latin America to deepen reforms.
newsitem.headline: World Bank urges Latin America to deepen reforms.

text.p: The World Bank wound up late Tuesday its third annual conference on Latin America during which it urged the region to deepen reforms to grow more than six percent a year to reduce poverty levels.

"Countries in Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC) have made substantial progress in achieving both macroeconomic stabilization and structural economic reform during the last decade," it said in a growth-plan called "The Long March."

But despite that growth, the proportion of the population living in poverty is about the same as it was at the beginning of the 1980's, when poverty grew strongly due to the regional debt crisis, it added.
Projections of annual growth rates range between four and five percent over the next few years for most LAC countries.
However, it said LAC economies need to grow more than six percent a year, "which is the growth rate widely belived necessary to lower the number of people living in poverty in the region."
